Slice . * * * Several minutes later , the rush faded as [I]441-you guys stared at [my]441-you guys reflection . Smiling , [I]441-you guys opened [my]441-you guys eyes and dialed [his]148-hutton number . TWO HUTTON [I]441-you guys used to think [I]441-you guys was magic . As [a kid]317-a kid , [I]441-you guys honestly believed [I]441-you guys could control [the world]301-the world just by doing certain things . Touching [my]441-you guys nose as [I]441-you guys entered [a room]314-the room . Stepping out of bed with [my]441-you guys right foot first , never [my]441-you guys left . Refusing to ride on the left side of the back seat in [[[my]441-you guys dad]241-my dad ’s car]320-the car , only the right . This often meant [I]441-you guys had to race out to [the driveway]321-the driveway early in order to beat [[my]441-you guys big sister [Allie]73-allie , who did not have magical powers no matter where [she]73-allie sat in [the car]320-the car]73-allie , but did have an incredible knack for pushing [my]441-you guys buttons . If the trip involved [the highway]322-the highway , [I]441-you guys had to sit with [my]441-you guys arms crossed without saying a word until [ten cars]323-ten cars passed . If [I]441-you guys saw [a tractor or motorcycle]324-a tractor or motorcycle , [I]441-you guys had to start over . If the trip in [the car]320-the car did not involve [the highway]322-the highway , [I]441-you guys had to hold [my]441-you guys feet off the floor the entire time , or at least until [we]325-we passed two stop signs or one traffic light . By doing these rituals but never speaking of [them]323-ten cars ( or else the magic would cease to work ) , [I]441-you guys was ensuring that all stayed right in [my]441-you guys world , which was pretty fucking great back then . In fifth grade , [I]441-you guys was one of [the most popular kids in [school]1440-school]326-the most popular kids in school . [I]441-you guys was good at math and baseball . [I]441-you guys was on [student council]328-student council and in the band . [I]441-you guys won the paper plate award for Most Likely to Go to Space and also an Astounding Attendance certificate , because [I]441-you guys never missed a day of school . ( Only [I]441-you guys knew that was because being absent or even tardy would alter the balance of the universe and possibly weaken [my]441-you guys powers , not because [I]441-you guys was never sick . ) Then a bunch of really shitty things happened , including puberty , and [my]441-you guys brain was completely rewired . That ’s when [I]441-you guys started to hate the phone . Or more specifically , the feeling of dread [I]441-you guys experienced when faced with being the sole focus of [someone]291-someone ’s attention on the other end of the line . [You]330-you were granted no time to think before [you]330-you had to answer questions — it was like a fastball coming straight for [your]330-you head . [You]330-you could n’t see [their]331-their reactions to anything [you]330-you said . [You]330-you had no idea how [they]331-their might be judging [you]330-you . [You]330-you had no opportunity to weigh the risk of any possible response . In contrast to a text or email , a phone conversation exposed [you]330-you completely . [I]441-you guys avoided [them]331-their at all costs . So when [my]441-you guys cell vibrated in [my]441-you guys back pocket as [I]441-you guys was about to leave [the house]243-the house , [I]441-you guys almost ignored it . If it mattered , [the caller]333-the caller would leave a voicemail .
